data.value: To view information about a specific location, click on the map...

data.name: noPlaceInfo

data.name: helpContent
data.value:
About MemoMap Prague

The MemoMap historical geographical information system displays data on more than 30,000 Holocaust victims, 1,700 cases of violations of anti-Jewish laws and regulations, and 200 points of interest onto an interactive map of Prague. MemoMap is designed as a mobile web application that allows users to conduct research not only from their homes or school computers, but also from their mobile phones while walking in the city.
The data on Holocaust victims comes from the Database of the Holocaust Victims maintained by the Terezín Initiative Institute. Thanks to its extensive digital archive, which contains digitized copies of selected documents from the Prague Police Directorate’s files and much more, it was possible to process data on more than 1,700 cases of violations of anti-Jewish laws and regulations and make it available on MemoMap. The app also includes points of interest, i.e. places connected to the everyday lives of Prague’s Jewish residents that were later directly related to their persecution. (...more)

Working with MemoMap

Viewing the layers of the map  
The individual data types are split into layers that the user can freely switch between while using the app. The option to select what layer to be displayed can be found in the main menu in the upper right corner of the screen.

Zooming in and out on the map   
The zoom in and zoom out buttons are located in the bottom right corner of the screen (or top-left corner in mobile view). They are only displayed while you are using the app on the computer. If you are working on your mobile device, you can zoom in and out using touch gestures.

Location service  
You can turn the position determination service on and off using the button on the bottom left corner of the screen (or top-left corner in mobile view). Activating the button allows you to see where you are on the map.

Acknowledgments

The project “Integration and Segregation in the City Space: The History of the Holocaust in Prague Through a Mobile Web Application (identifier TL01000366) was supported by the Technology Agency of the Czech Republic as part of the public ÉTA 1 program. The MemoMap application was created by the Masaryk Institute and Archives of the Czech Academy of Sciences in cooperation with the Terezín Initiative Institute and the Multicultural Center in Prague.

Have you found an error?

If you’ve encountered a technical problem or error in the data displayed, please use the report form and let us know.

data.name: survivorsNotDisplayed
data.value: Survivors and people of unknown fate aren't displayed below.

data.name: layer_interest_title
data.value: Points of Interest in the City of Prague

data.name: layer_interest_abstract
data.value: Points of interest include places of persecution, Jewish buildings, warehouses full of confiscated property, or places that Jews were forbidden to enter.

data.name: layer_incident_title
data.value: Incidents Within the City of Prague

data.name: layer_incident_abstract
data.value: Incidents that took place within the city limits of Prague during which Jewish residents were arrested or investigated for violating anti-Jewish ordinances. This data was extracted from the digitized documents of the Prague Police as part of the MemoMap Prague project. It includes information about non-compliance with restrictions of free movement, identification papers lacking the letter \"J\" (Jude), etc.

data.name: layer_inaccessible_abstract
data.value: Places that Jews were forbidden to enter. Based on the historical map from year 1938. Current shape of the place can differ.

data.name: layer_inaccessible_title
data.value: Forbidden Places Within the City of Prague

data.name: layer_victim_abstract
data.value: Database of Jewish residents of Prague who were persecuted by the Nazis and died as a result. The records are linked to their Prague addresses. Details are accessible via links to holocaust.cz.

data.name: layer_address_title
data.value: Jewish Homes in Prague During the Occupation

data.name: layer_address_abstract
data.value: The home addresses of Prague's Jewish residents during the Shoah from the victims' database. The data mostly comes from the registration of Jews in the Protectorate, which began in the fall of 1941 by order of the Central Office for Jewish Emigration. You will be able to view the number of people who lived in a particular building, find out what their fates were, and the numbers of those present on various historical dates. Some buildings were difficult to identify and in those cases multiple addresses (for example, on the same street) are grouped under the same coordinates. We are continually working on refining the map. We have kept the street names used during the occupation (roughly 1941-1942).

data.name: layer_statistics_abstract
data.value: Statistic information on number of Jewish residents, incidents and points of interest according to specific Prague's districts. Zoom in to display details.

data.name: layer_MGS-prague_historical_map_1938-v2_abstract
data.value: Orientační plán hlavního města Prahy s okolím (1938) [Orientation plan of the capital city of Prague with its surroundings (1938)].Digitized by by the Municipal Library in Prague, georeferenced by the Masaryk Institute and archives of the Czech Academy of Sciences. Also available from WWW: http://web2.mlp.cz/mapa1938/klad.php.

data.name: zoomMapForMoreInfo
data.value: Zoom in on the map for more information.

data.name: welcomeText
data.value:
The MemoMap historical geographical information system displays data on more than 30,000 Holocaust victims, 1,700 cases of violations of anti-Jewish laws and regulations, and 200 points of interest onto an interactive map of European cities.

Jewish residents

Places where, according to the victims' database, Jewish inhabitants lived at the time of the Holocaust.

Incidents

Incidents in the city area in which Jewish residents were arrested or investigated for violating anti-Jewish laws and regulations.

Points of Interest

Sites of persecution, Jewish buildings and warehouses of confiscated property.

Forbidden places

Places inaccessible to Jews. Zobrazení je založeno na historické mapě z roku 1938, současné prostory se mohou lišit velikostí i tvarem.

data.name: layerHelp
data.value: You can filter the results according to selected layers...

data.name: helpSearch
data.value: Full-text search allows you to search for victims' residences, incidents and points of interest. Simply enter, for example, the name of the person or place you are looking for.

data.name: addressOccupation
data.value: German address from the time of the occupation
